wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 1/16/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top articles from around the industry so that you can stay up-to-date on the state of employee engagement in CSR and sustainability on the go.

How Brands Can Attract Millennials Looking For Meaningful Work

This month, millenials began outnumbering their older colleagues in the workplace. How do companies need to change recruitment efforts for this new breed of worker? A new report suggests recruiting for top talent before they graduate, work hard to overlap social good and meaning into the position, and focus on the non-monetary forms of compensation.

What Motivates Employees?

If you’ve ever tried to define employee engagement, then you understand the difficulty around the topic. Bersin by Deloitte is working to change current notions about engagement to commitment. Research shows that development opportunities and leadership have 3-4 times greater impact on retention than relationships with immediate managers. Bersin encourages companies to craft themselves as Irresistible Organizations.

90% of Americans More Likely to Trust Brands That Back Social Causes

Consumers have come to expect companies to incorporate social good into their business models. Research shows that 88% of consumers would buy a product with a social or environmental benefit, and 84% would tell friends and family about a company’s CSR efforts. It’s recommended that brands can communicate their social good efforts by authoring genuine original content and tapping into social media.

Employee Engagement Depends on What Happens Outside of the Office

A former HR leader of a Fortune 500 company explains that most employee engagement models are centered around the work experience and not on the employees. Traditionally, companies only try to understand and affect what happens at work, not the whole self or life of an employee. The author’s research found that the root causes of engagement are actually found outside the workplace and offers a framework of how to connect with employees at a deeper level (work-life balance).

Patagonia CEO Rose Marcario Fights the Fight Worth Fighting

Patagonia has been a leader in apparel activism and environmental issues. An interview with Rose gives an up close and personal look into Patagonia’s success and values. Our favorite quote: If there’s one thing companies should do today, it’s become a for-benefit corporation. It says, Look, profit is important, but what’s just as important is the environment and the community.
